prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: For the line detection, we will use the low resolution FDM with dual polarization, a bandwidth of 1875 MHz, and a resolution of 976.56 kHz (2.7-2.8 km/s at the observed frequencies). This resolution is enough to fully resolve a line of 150 km/s (corresponding to 5 channels within the expected line width). Given the low redshift of the blazar (z=0.069), we will observe the CO line in the Upper Side Band using two basebands placed at 575 MHz above and below the CO(1-0) frequency in the observed frame. In this configuration, the two basebands will overlap by 720 MHz (~2000 km/s), yielding a contiguous bandwidth of 3 GHz (~8500 km/s) centered on the CO emission line. This velocity interval is large enough to accomodate any uncertainty that is associated to the optical redshifts. Further, this velocity window is wide enough to optimally characterize and subtract the baseline. The two remaining basebands will be placed in the Lower Side Band where, using the low resolution TDM and dual polarization, we will map the continuum emission at 3mm over a total bandwidth of 4 GHz. These data points will be used in the analysis of the blazar SED.

Since most of the CO emission is believed to originate within the inner 1 or at most few kpc of the host galaxy center [2], the main beam in band 3 (>50 arcsec) will clearly encompass all the emitting regions. We will use the most compact configuration (C32-1), which yields a resolution of ~3.4-3.6 arcsec. This is sufficient to recover all the flux from the source (<~3 arcsec for blazars), but at the same time it does not over-resolve the source (1 arcsec corresponds to 1 kpc at z=0.05), avoiding the loss of power on large scales.

Our sensitivity calculations are based on the pilot observations at the IRAM 30-m telescope (Figure 3, [2]). We aim to detect the CO(1-0) emission line at rest (nu=115.27120 GHz) with a CO luminosity of more than ~5x10^7 K km/s pc^2. Based on the observations of 1ES 1959+650 (Figure 3), we further expect a line width of ~150 km/s. Since we aim to resolve the line profile with at least 5 resolution elements, we will Hanning smooth the data to a final resolution of 30 km/s and we assume this velocity in the sensitivity calculation.
At the corresponding distance of PKS 0548-322 (z=0.069), the sensitivity required to detect a greater than 3 sigma line with these characteristics translates to a rms noise level of 0.40 mJy.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The superb collecting area of ALMA and the exquisite sensitivity of band 3 has now opened a new path to understand blazar origin and evolution. In this proposal, we aim to collect observations of the CO(1-0) emission line in four very-high-energy gamma-ray blazars with redshifts of z<=0.1. The first objective of this proposal is to empirically test whether nearby blazars do, in fact, lack a large reservoir of molecular gas, as predicted by models of inefficient accretion flows. Second, we wish to establish whether there is a clear correlation between the characteristic spectral energy distribution in blazars and the gaseous content of the host galaxies, a fundamental assumption within the current evolutionary paradigm for blazars. Next, the proposed observations will provide conclusive evidence for the postulated existence of soft photons from the thermal emission of the accretion disk that are responsible, via Compton scattering, of the gamma-ray emission in blazars. Finally, we aim to explore an innovative means to constrain the energy spectrum of the relativistic particles within the blazar jets.
